Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cognitive Radio with 2-D Cognition: Dynamic Spectrum vs. Power Accesses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project focuses on the fundamental tradeoff between spectrum efficiency and energy efficiency in cognitive radio systems by exploring the correlations across both spectrum and energy domains, in the notions of both frequency holes and energy holes. The considered application scenario is a spectrum sharing system with both legacy and cognitive radios, where the nodes are powered by either smart grids or environment energy harvesters or a mix of two. The three main research objectives are: develop joint 2-D sensing scheme to explore the correlation between frequency holes and energy holes; derive efficiency maximizing resource allocation schemes considering constraints in both energy and spectrum domains; and study performance enhancement mechanisms in the framework of collaborative clouds via node conferencing. Novel interdisciplinary approaches are applied to combine the methods of 2-D statistical signal processing, non-convex optimization, and analytical energy harvesting system modeling to study the unique problem considered for the newly defined cognitive radio systems with 2-D cognition. The project provides both theories and algorithms for energy-efficient operation of future cognitive radio systems with accesses to both spectrum and energy dynamics. The research findings will be incorporated into graduate courses; the results will be disseminated to the community via journal papers and conference presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A typical cognitive radio (CR) provides a dynamic spectrum access architecture that could operate over a spectrum sensing based opportunistic access paradigm in the existence of primary radios, where the cognition is expressed by intelligently exploring the secondary vs. primary spectrum access correlations and the goal is to maximize the overall spectrum efficiency without hurting the primary radio performance. Besides spectrum efficiency, energy efficiency has been in focus recently due to the motivations for future green communication systems. In systems powered by traditional power grids, the notation of power access is meaningless since the power usages across different users are almost independent of each other.

However, in systems powered by the emerging smart grid or environment energy harvesters, power suddenly becomes a multiple access medium since the power usages across different users (especially geographically neighboring ones) are dependent on each other. Such correlations could be explored within the power access framework to enhance the overall energy efficiency or even help with improving the spectrum efficiency, since the spectrum access and power access are actually correlated events.

 

In this project, we focused on the fundamental tradeoff between spectrum efficiency and energy efficiency in cognitive radio systems by exploring the correlations across both spectrum and power domains, in the notions of both spectrum holes and energy holes. In particular, we considered a coexisting system with both primary and cognitive radios, where the nodes are powered by either smart grids or environment energy harvesters or a mix of two. We have set the following research goals: 1) Develop joint 2-D sensing schemes to explore the correlation between spectrum holes and energy holes; 2) derive efficiency maximizing resource allocation schemes considering constraints over both power access and spectrum access; and 3) study performance enhancement mechanisms in the framework of collaborative clouds via node conferencing, which enables more efficient exploration of the proposed 2-D cognition. In particular, we have been focusing on the following five research efforts: 1) Wideband sensing via spatial cooperation; 2) Efficient resource allocation in energy harvesting based random spectrum access systems; 3) optimal resource allocation in fading channels with energy harvesting constraints; 4) Sparsity based wideband cooperative spectrum sensing; 5) Power vs. spectrum two-dimensional sensing for energy harvesting based cognitive radio systems. For each effort, specific algorithms were developed with performance guarantees proved by theorems. Furthermore, all the analytical results were validated with thorough numerical simulations.

 

The intellectual merits lied in the interdisciplinary approach to combine the methods of wireless communication, signal processing, optimization, information theory, and power systems to study the unique problem considered for the newly defined CR systems with 2-D cognition. The proposed methodology is transformative, and the results will lead to novel schemes for optimally operating CR systems with accesses to both spectrum dynamics and power dynamics.

 

The research outcome will also have significant and multi-fold impacts on the societies. The results will help enable efficiency-optimal operations of future cognitive radio systems with 2-D cognition. Furthermore, the PI conducted a concurrent and integrated education program, which addressed the undergraduate and graduate education issues in multiple aspects: teaching, training, and mentoring.
